text: Bearing a cyclical date of 1353, this rare ceramic ink stone is carved in the shape of a low table. The work accurately suggests a softwood furniture form popular in the Sung (960-1279) and Yuan (1280-1368) dynasties. Block-like ink stones were popular from Sung through Ch'ing. They were heavy enough to make the ink-grinding easy, and their tall sides easily accommodated carved designs or inscriptions. While it resembled tuan stone, ceramic stoneware was a less expensive material, and this ink stone, while important for its carved subject and inscribed date, is considerably less refined in its carving than the later stone example shown here.
title: Ink Stone in the Form of a Low Table
